title: Get started
text: important understand transition probabilities provided smktrans static. Smoking behaviour dynamic, understanding evolves new survey data becomes available methodological refinements made. Therefore, package operates versioned basis: Updates: new health survey data released refine algorithms, package version incremented. Snapshots: version package produces specific set estimates. Access: can download specific probability estimates England, Scotland, Wales Articles tab website. recommend always checking package version ensure using current estimates modelling work.

title: Get started
text: estimates produced smktrans direct result calibration fitting standard statistical model (e.g. logistic regression prediction). Instead, result applying mathematical algorithm based rearrangement formula dynamics smoking prevalence. See Sheffield Tobacco Policy Model Technical Documentation.

title: Get started
text: foundation methodology work Holford et al. (2014) United States. established workflow estimating smoking state transition probabilities repeat cross-sectional survey data. adapted approach UK context. core logic involves taking observed cross-sectional prevalence (“stocks” smokers non-smokers specific time) calculating necessary flows (transitions) required maintain change stocks, accounting : Mortality: integrate external information disease-specific mortality rates account differential survival smokers, former smokers, never smokers. Long-term (>1 year): Based Hawkins et al. (2010) using British Household Panel Survey. Short-term (<1 year): Derived placebo condition Jackson et al. (2019). Full technical details can found STPM Technical Documentation methodological vignette found articles tab smktrans website.

title: Get started
text: estimates generated smktrans formed evidence base major tobacco control policy decisions UK.

what: 1. England: The Royal College of Physicians & The SmokeFree Generation
title: Get started
text: transition probabilities originally developed England. first major application informing projections Section 2.6 Royal College Physicians’ 2021 report, “Smoking health 2021: coming age tobacco control?” President RCP noted introduction: > “Instead, modelling current tobacco control policies shows failure achieve smoking prevalence <5% 2050.” Following , methodology utilized knowledge exchange project Office Health Improvement Disparities (OHID). understanding produced collaboration later supported government’s internal modelling SmokeFree Generation policy. Tobacco Vapes Bill introduced Parliament, smktrans estimates used government modelling team final Impact Assessment. * See page 34 Tobacco Vapes Bill Impact Assessment.

title: Get started
text: Funded SPECTRUM Consortium, extended methodology Scotland. estimates informed report commissioned Public Health Scotland potential effects minimum pricing tobacco. * Read report: Model-based appraisal potential effects minimum pricing tobacco Scotland. * Read peer-reviewed publication: Gillespie et al. (2025) Tobacco Control.

title: Get started
text: Work currently ongoing use estimates Wales, supported commissioned knowledge exchange project Public Health Wales. begun work data science team integrate smktrans methodology internal analytic workflows.

title: Get started
text: credibility smktrans estimates extends beyond University Sheffield research team. independently adopted academic groups inform peer-reviewed simulation studies. notably, Davies et al. (2026) utilized estimates model potential inequality impacts SmokeFree Generation policy England. * Read publication: Davies N, Murray R, Morling JR, et al. (2026). Impact UK’s smokefree generation policy tobacco-related equity England: simulation study. Tobacco Control.

title: Get started
text: smktrans estimates continue evolve. currently form backbone tobacco pricing modelling using TAX-sim (developed NIHR SYNTAX project). recently informed modelling effects changes tobacco tax England: Read peer-reviewed publication: Chen et al. (2026) Tobacco Control. Furthermore, now using quitting probability estimates calibration targets new Agent-Based Models (ABM) designed understand behavioural mechanisms underlying quit attempts maintenance. Read peer-reviewed publication: Tian et al. (2026) Winter Simulation Conference.

title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: vignette provides step--step guide estimating annual probabilities smoking initiation, quitting, relapse using smktrans package. estimates underpin Sheffield Tobacco Policy Model (STPM). core philosophy workflow consistency. estimate rates isolation; instead, use “Stock Flow” approach robustly measured number smokers (Stock) used solve unobservable quit rates (Flow).

title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: following diagram illustrates raw survey data transformed consistent transition matrix.

title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: Objective: Estimate probability Never Smoker becoming Smoker age xx year tt. Challenge: Older people often forget exactly started smoking (“Recall Bias”). Furthermore, differential mortality means early initiators less likely survive surveyed older age. Using raw recall data alone suggest initiation rates lower past actually . Solution: Holford Method. reconstruct histories based reported starting ages (subject bias) adjust match robust “Ever-Smoker” prevalence directly observed year. Reconstruct (init_est): Builds “Risk Set” every cohort using cross-sectional recall. Target (ever_smoke): Fits Generalized Linear Model (Quasibinomial) estimate true proportion Ever-Smokers age 30. Calibrate (init_adj): Scales raw curves cumulative sum matches targets.
code: # 1. Reconstruct longitudinal histories from cross-sectional recall init_raw <- init_est(   data = survey_data,   strat_vars = c("sex", "imd_quintile") )  # 2. Estimate the 'Truth': Proportion of ever-smokers at age 25-34 # We use Model 8 (Sex + IMD + Year_Bin) for a stable target target_trends <- ever_smoke(   data = survey_data,   model = "model8",    age_cats = c("25-34") )  # 3. Adjust the curves using the Holford method # This corrects the recall bias to match the 'truth' at age 30 init_final <- init_adj(   init_data = init_raw,   ever_smoke_data = target_trends$predicted_values,   ref_age = 30 )

title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: Objective: Estimate probability Former Smoker becoming Current Smoker. Challenge: Relapse risk depends heavily Time Since Quit (TSQ). relapse happens year 1. However, general cross-sectional surveys rarely capture enough long-term quitters estimate late-stage relapse (5+ years post-quit) reliably. Solution: combine survey demographics clinical evidence (Hawkins et al., 2010) provides shape relapse hazard curve. Map (prep_relapse): Calculates weighted average relapse probability every Age/Sex/IMD group mapping specific characteristics Hawkins hazard ratios. Forecast (relapse_forecast): Projects general trend forward applies scalar detailed TSQ curves.
code: # 1. Map survey demographics to Hawkins' clinical hazard ratios relapse_data <- prep_relapse(   data = survey_data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse )  # 2. Forecast the trend and apply it to the detailed Time-Since-Quit data # Note: relapse_trend_forecast is derived from a preliminary run of quit_forecast relapse_final <- relapse_forecast(   relapse_forecast_data = relapse_trend_forecast,    relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit = relapse_data$relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit )

what: Phase 3: Trends in Current, Former and Never Smoking (The Stock)
title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: can solve quitting, need clear picture “Stock” (Prevalence) “Leak” (Mortality).

previous_headings: Phase 3: Trends in Current, Former and Never Smoking (The Stock)
title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: Raw survey prevalence noisy. calculate year--year flows jagged data. fit Multinomial Response Surface smooth data time age. model assumes log-odds specific state function high-order interactions:ln(PstatePref)=f(Age4,Year3,Sex,IMD)\ln\left(\frac{P_{state}}{P_{ref}}\right) = f(\text{Age}^4, \text{Year}^3, \text{Sex}, \text{IMD})

previous_headings: Phase 3: Trends in Current, Former and Never Smoking (The Stock)
title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: Smokers die faster non-smokers. ignore , might mistake drop smoker numbers (due death) quitting. calculate survival probabilities (pxp_x) specifically Current, Former, Never smokers using disease-specific relative risks.
code: # 1. Fit a smooth surface to the smoking states (Multinomial Model) trend_surface <- trend_fit(   data = survey_data,   max_iterations = 1000,   smoker_state_var = "smk.state" )  # 2. Calculate survival probabilities by smoking status mortality_diffs <- smoke_surv(   data = survey_data,   mx_data = tob_mort_data,   diseases = tobalcepi::tob_disease_names )

title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: Objective: Calculate “Hidden Flow” (Quitting). Logic: rely demographic balancing equation. possess following knowns: 1. Stock (Nt,Nt+1N_t, N_{t+1}): trend_fit. 2. Inflow (Start): init_adj. 3. Reflow (Relapse): prep_relapse. 4. Death (Survival SS): smoke_surv. plug Flow Equation solve unknown Quit probability (qq). fundamental population balance : Nt+1=[Nt×S×(1−q)]+InflowN_{t+1} = \left[ N_t \times S \times (1 - q) \right] + \text{Inflow} Rearranging solve qq: q=1−Nt+1Nt×S+InflowNt×Sq = 1 - \frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t \times S} + \frac{\text{Inflow}}{N_t \times S}Inflow includes Relapse Initiation. ensures internal consistency: calculated quit rates perfectly reproduce observed prevalence trends run forward.
code: # Solve for the unknown variable: Quitting # This function balances the stocks and flows quit_rates <- quit_est(   trend_data = trend_surface,   survivorship_data = survivorship_data,   mortality_data = mortality_diffs$data_for_quit_ests,   relapse_data = relapse_data$relapse_by_age_imd,   initiation_data = init_final )

title: Workflow for Estimating Smoking Transition Probabilities
text: Objective: Project rates 2040 beyond. Solution: Lee-Carter SVD Method. employ Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) approach, commonly used mortality forecasting. allows us model logit rates linear combination age-specific profile time-varying index. logit(Px,t)=αx+βxκt+ϵx,t\text{logit}(P_{x,t}) = \alpha_x + \beta_x \kappa_t + \epsilon_{x,t} : * αx\alpha_x: average age profile (e.g., quitting peaks age 30 60). * κt\kappa_t: time trend index (e.g., general decline rise rates years). * βx\beta_x: sensitivity age group time trend. project Trend (κt\kappa_t) forward linearly recombine Shape (αx,βx\alpha_x, \beta_x).
code: # Forecast Quitting quit_future <- quit_forecast(   data = quit_rates,   forecast_var = "p_quit",   forecast_type = "continuing",   time_horizon = 2040 )  # Forecast Initiation (using the same function) init_future <- quit_forecast(   data = init_final,   forecast_var = "p_start",   forecast_type = "continuing",   time_horizon = 2040 )

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: smktrans R package provides methodological framework automated workflow estimating probabilities individuals transitioning smoking states (initiation, quitting, relapse) using repeat cross-sectional survey data. core component Sheffield Tobacco Alcohol Policy Modelling (STAPM) platform, specifically designed generate transition parameters Sheffield Tobacco Policy Model (STPM).

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: Cohort Reconstruction: Methods derive longitudinal-style life histories cross-sectional survey data. “Quit Solver”: mathematical approach estimating age-specific quit rates reconciling changes smoking prevalence known initiation, relapse mortality rates. Long-term Forecasting: Tools project transition probabilities extended time horizons (e.g., 2040) support policy impact assessments. Data Stratification: Estimation age, sex, Index Multiple Deprivation (IMD) quintiles.

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: comprehensive guides package usage detailed methodology, please refer Articles section package website. Key documentation includes: Package Workflow: step--step guide estimation process. Methodological Documentation: Technical details “Quit Solver” cohort reconstruction. Accessing Estimates: Presentation pre-calculated estimates England, Scotland, Wales.

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: package can installed GitHub. Please note smktrans depends several internal STAPM packages data processing mortality adjustment.
code: # install.packages("remotes")  # 1. Install STAPM dependencies remotes::install_github("stapm-platform/hseclean") remotes::install_github("stapm-platform/tobalcepi") remotes::install_github("stapm-platform/mort.tools")  # 2. Install smktrans remotes::install_github("stapm-platform/smktrans")

code: bin_var(x, n_bins)

title: Bin numeric variable — bin_var
text: Returns numeric binned variable

what: Build Web Reports for Pkgdown — build_web_reports
title: Build Web Reports for Pkgdown — build_web_reports
text: Generates RMarkdown wrapper files vignettes/articles. wrappers load saved configuration render report body.

title: Build Web Reports for Pkgdown — build_web_reports
code: build_web_reports()

what: Calculate Net Initiation Probabilities (Synthetic Cohort) — calculate_net_initiation
title: Calculate Net Initiation Probabilities (Synthetic Cohort) — calculate_net_initiation
text: Calculates "Net Initiation" probabilities simulating synthetic cohort starting age 12. metric represents net flow "Current Smoker" state (Initiation + Relapse - Quitting) relative non-smoking population age. solves issue high initiation rates young ages offset high quit rates (experimentation vs. established smoking).

title: Calculate Net Initiation Probabilities (Synthetic Cohort) — calculate_net_initiation
code: calculate_net_initiation(init_data, quit_data, relapse_data, pops, config)

title: Calculate Net Initiation Probabilities (Synthetic Cohort) — calculate_net_initiation
text: init_data Data.table. Initiation probabilities. quit_data Data.table. Quit probabilities. relapse_data Data.table. Relapse probabilities (must contain 'time_since_quit'). pops Data.table. Population weights. config List. Must contain 'country' uncertainty params ('kn', 'kn_samp', 'kR').

title: Calculate Net Initiation Probabilities (Synthetic Cohort) — calculate_net_initiation
text: Assumptions: cohort starts age 12 100 Relapse probabilities selected based age-specific assumptions         average time since quitting:         (12-17: 1yr, 18-24: 3yrs, 25-30: 5yrs).

what: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Initiation — estimate_initiation
title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Initiation — estimate_initiation
text: 1. Estimates historical initiation (cumulative -> density). 2. Forecasts future initiation using `quit_forecast` (continuing trend). 3. Saves raw, adjusted, forecasted outputs.

title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Initiation — estimate_initiation
code: estimate_initiation(config, survey_data)

title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Initiation — estimate_initiation
text: config List. Must contain: first_year, last_year, min_age, max_age, ref_age, smokefree_target_year, age_trend_limit_init, smooth_rate_dim_init, k_smooth_age_init.

what: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Quitting — estimate_quitting
title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Quitting — estimate_quitting
text: 1. Trend fitting & Mortality calculation. 2. Historical Quit Solver. 3. Forecasts Quit rates (continuing trend). 4. Forecasts 'Initiation' Quit rates (counterfactual).

title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Quitting — estimate_quitting
code: estimate_quitting(config, survey_data, tob_mort_data, tob_mort_data_cause)

what: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Relapse — estimate_relapse
title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Relapse — estimate_relapse
text: 1. Prepares base relapse rates (Hawkins). 2. Forecasts Age/Sex/IMD specific trend using `quit_forecast`. 3. Scales Time-Since-Quit data using `relapse_forecast`. 4. Imputes data ages < 18.

title: Estimate and Forecast Smoking Relapse — estimate_relapse
code: estimate_relapse(config, survey_data)

what: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking — ever_smoke
title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking — ever_smoke
text: Fits survey-weighted GLM (quasibinomial) trend ever-smoking age 25-34. provides "target" level Holford adjustment.

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking — ever_smoke
code: ever_smoke(   data,   time_horizon = 2100,   num_bins = 7,   model = "model2",   min_age = 15,   min_year = 2003,   age_cats = c("25-34") )

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking — ever_smoke
text: data Data table individual characteristics. time_horizon Integer - last year projection. num_bins Integer - bins period trend reduce noise. model Character - Model specification (interaction terms). min_age Integer - youngest age prediction. min_year Integer - first year survey data. age_cats Character vector - age category reference (e.g., "25-34").

what: Generate Uncertainty Intervals for Transition Probabilities — generate_uncertainty
title: Generate Uncertainty Intervals for Transition Probabilities — generate_uncertainty
text: Estimates uncertainty around transition probabilities using Beta distribution assumption derived binomial variance sample size. generates correlated Monte Carlo samples (using Gaussian Copula) preserve relationship age/cohort groups across iterations. process follows steps: 1. Standard Error: Calculates SE based effective sample size (\(SE = \sqrt{p(1-p)/n}\)). 2. Beta Parameters: Converts Mean (p) Variance (SE^2) Beta shape parameters (\(\alpha, \beta\)). 3. Correlated Sampling: Generates matrix correlated uniform probabilities using Gaussian Copula. Common factor \(Z_{shared}\) accounts systematic uncertainty. Idiosyncratic factor \(Z_{indiv}\) accounts random noise. 4. Inverse CDF: Maps probabilities qbeta function get final samples.

title: Generate Uncertainty Intervals for Transition Probabilities — generate_uncertainty
code: generate_uncertainty(data, prob_col, n_eff, n_samp, correlation)

title: Generate Uncertainty Intervals for Transition Probabilities — generate_uncertainty
text: data Data table. Must contain probability column. prob_col Character. Name column containing point estimate probabilities (e.g., "p_start"). n_eff Numeric. effective sample size used calculate variance. Higher n implies narrower confidence intervals. n_samp Integer. Number Monte Carlo samples generate (e.g., 100 1000). correlation Numeric (0-1). correlation coefficient (\(R\)) rows single sample iteration. High correlation implies one age group overestimated, others likely .

title: Generate Uncertainty Intervals for Transition Probabilities — generate_uncertainty
text: list containing: data: original data table added summary columns         (_low, _median, _high, _var). samples: matrix dimensions [nrow(data) x n_samp] containing simulated values.

what: Long-term probabilities of smoking relapse — hawkins_relapse
title: Long-term probabilities of smoking relapse — hawkins_relapse

title: Long-term probabilities of smoking relapse — hawkins_relapse
text: Hawkins J, Hollingworth W, Campbell R (2010). “Long-term smoking relapse: study using british household panel survey.” Nicotine & tobacco research, 12(12), 1228–1235.

title: Death rates for England & Wales — hmd_data_eng

what: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking (Holford Method) — init_adj
title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking (Holford Method) — init_adj
text: Calibrates retrospective recall data observed period trends using Holford (2014) method. ensures cohort histories sum match "truth" seen cross-sectional surveys specific ages.

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking (Holford Method) — init_adj
code: init_adj(   init_data,   ever_smoke_data,   ref_age = 30,   fix_ref_age = FALSE,   min_ref = 25,   cohorts = 1973:2020,   period_start = 2003,   period_end = 2018 )

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking (Holford Method) — init_adj
text: init_data Data table - raw estimates init_est(). ever_smoke_data Data table - trend targets ever_smoke(). ref_age Integer - index age calibration (default 30). fix_ref_age Logical. TRUE, forces ref_age even data sparse. min_ref Integer - minimum age allow reference. cohorts Integer vector - cohorts adjust. period_start Integer - first year data. period_end Integer - last year data.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation — init_est
text: Reconstructs longitudinal smoking histories cross-sectional recall data.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation — init_est
code: init_est(data, strat_vars = c("sex", "imd_quintile"))

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation — init_est
text: data Data table individual characteristics. Must contain 'start_age'. strat_vars Character vector stratification variables.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation — init_est
text: summarized data.table initiation probabilities age/year/cohort.

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities — prep_relapse
text: Combines published estimates long-term relapse (Hawkins 2010) population survey data. maps probabilities onto survey population's demographic structure (education, mental health, etc.) derive aggregate relapse rates Age, Sex, IMD, Time Since Quit.

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities — prep_relapse
code: prep_relapse(   data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse,   lowest_year = 2003,   highest_year = 2018,   youngest_age = 18 )

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities — prep_relapse
text: data Data table individual survey data. hawkins_relapse Data table Hawkins et al. odds ratios/probs. lowest_year Integer. highest_year Integer. youngest_age Integer.

what: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship — prep_surv
title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship — prep_surv
text: Combines long-term historical mortality rates (HMD) recent socioeconomically stratified mortality data (ONS) produce cohort survivorship curves (lx) stratified Age, Sex, IMD Quintile.

title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship — prep_surv
code: prep_surv(   mx_data_hmd = smktrans::hmd_data_eng,   mx_data_ons,   min_age = 11,   max_age = 89,   min_year = 2003,   max_year = 2018 )

title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship — prep_surv
text: mx_data_hmd Data table HMD mortality rates (1922+). mx_data_ons Data table ONS stratified mortality rates. min_age, max_age, min_year, max_year Integers defining scope.

what: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities — p_dense
title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities — p_dense
text: Converts Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) ever-smoking Probability Density Function (PDF), represents probability initiating smoking specific age.

title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities — p_dense
code: p_dense(   data,   cum_func_var,   strat_vars = c("cohort", "sex", "imd_quintile"),   lowest_year = 2003,   max_year = 2100 )

title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities — p_dense
text: data Data table cumulative probabilities. cum_func_var Character - name cumulative variable. strat_vars Character vector - stratification variables. lowest_year integer - start year filter. max_year integer - end year filter.

what: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values — p_smooth
title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values — p_smooth
text: Applies 2D moving average smooth trends age period, fills remaining missing values approximating age pattern within particular year.

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values — p_smooth
code: p_smooth(data, value_var, window_size = 3)

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values — p_smooth
text: data Data table containing "age", "year" variable bounded 0 1. value_var Character - name variable smoothed. window_size - Integer - must odd number - number years covered moving average window.

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values — p_smooth
text: Returns data table data smoothed probability values.

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values — p_smooth
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ test_data <- data.frame(expand.grid(age = c(12:40, 42:89), year = 2001:2016)) setDT(test_data) test_data[ , prob := runif(nrow(test_data))] test_data[sample(1:nrow(test_data), 100, replace = F), prob := NA]  data_sm <- p_smooth(test_data, "prob", 3) } # }

what: Estimate smoking quit probabilities (The Flow Equation) — quit_est
title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities (The Flow Equation) — quit_est
text: Calculates probability quitting required balance population stocks (Current, Former, Never) given flows (Initiation, Relapse, Mortality).

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities (The Flow Equation) — quit_est
code: quit_est(   trend_data,   survivorship_data,   mortality_data,   relapse_data,   initiation_data,   min_age = 11,   max_age = 89,   min_year = 2003,   max_year = 2018 )

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities (The Flow Equation) — quit_est
text: trend_data Output trend_fit(). survivorship_data Output prep_surv(). mortality_data Output smoke_surv(). relapse_data Output prep_relapse() (aggregated version). initiation_data Output init_adj(). min_age, max_age, min_year, max_year Integers.

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities (The Flow Equation) — quit_est
text: Solves equation: N(t+1) = N(t) * Survival * (1 - Quit) + (Former * Relapse) + (Never * Init) Rearranged solve Quit.

what: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse — quit_forecast
title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse — quit_forecast
text: Forecasts trends transition probabilities using Lee-Carter style Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) model.

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse — quit_forecast
code: quit_forecast(   data,   forecast_var,   forecast_type = c("continuing", "stationary"),   cont_limit = NULL,   oldest_year = 2003,   youngest_age = 11,   oldest_age = 88,   age_cont_limit = 88,   first_year = 2010,   jump_off_year = 2015,   time_horizon = 2050,   smooth_rate_dim = c(3, 3),   k_smooth_age = 3 )

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse — quit_forecast
text: data Data table input probabilities. forecast_var Character - variable forecast. forecast_type "continuing" (linear trend) "stationary" (constant). cont_limit Integer - year forecast becomes stationary. oldest_year Integer - start historical data. youngest_age Integer - min age. oldest_age Integer - max age. first_year Integer - start year trend fitting. jump_off_year Integer - end year historical data. time_horizon Integer - end year forecast. smooth_rate_dim Vector - dimensions raster smoothing (c(3,3)). k_smooth_age Integer - knots smoothing age component.

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse — quit_forecast
text: model assumes logit probability can decomposed : Logit(P_xt) = Alpha_x + Beta_x * Kappa_t : - Alpha_x: Average age profile - Kappa_t: Time trend index - Beta_x: Sensitivity age time trend

title: Forecast relapse probabilities (Time-Since-Quit Stratified) — relapse_forecast
text: Applies trends forecast `quit_forecast` (Age/Sex/IMD) detailed Time-Since-Quit data. calculates scaling factor "jump-" year applies future years.

title: Forecast relapse probabilities (Time-Since-Quit Stratified) — relapse_forecast
code: relapse_forecast(   relapse_forecast_data,   relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit,   jump_off_year = 2018 )

title: Forecast relapse probabilities (Time-Since-Quit Stratified) — relapse_forecast
text: relapse_forecast_data Data table - output quit_forecast() (trend). relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit Data table - detailed base rates prep_relapse(). jump_off_year Integer.

what: smktrans: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data — smktrans-package
title: smktrans: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data — smktrans-package
text: Estimates probabilities individuals initiate, quit relapse regular cigarette smoking cross-sectional survey data.

title: smktrans: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data — smktrans-package
text: Maintainer: Duncan Gillespie duncan.gillespie@sheffield.ac.uk (ORCID) Authors: Alan Brennan .brennan@sheffield.ac.uk (ORCID) contributors: Laura Webster (ORCID) (Original code methodology) [contributor] Grace Leeming g.leeming@sheffield.ac.uk (ORCID) (Code extension Scotland) [contributor] Robin Purshouse (Methodological review feedback) [contributor] Hazel Squires (Methodological review feedback) [contributor] Shangshang Gu (Methodological review feedback) [contributor]

what: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status — smoke_surv
title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status — smoke_surv

title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status — smoke_surv
code: smoke_surv(   data,   diseases = tobalcepi::tob_disease_names,   mx_data,   min_age = 11,   max_age = 89,   min_year = 2003,   max_year = 2018 )

title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status — smoke_surv
text: data Data table individual characteristics (survey data). diseases Character vector disease names. mx_data Data table cause-specific mortality rates. min_age, max_age, min_year, max_year Integers.

what: Summarise and Plot Smoking Transition Probabilities — summarise_smoking_transitions
title: Summarise and Plot Smoking Transition Probabilities — summarise_smoking_transitions
text: Generates summary plots tables estimated transition probabilities. creates: 1. Population-weighted time trends (Initiation, Relapse, Quit). 2. Age-specific profiles (uncertainty ribbons). 3. Combined panels publication. 4. Summary CSV tables specific subgroups.

title: Summarise and Plot Smoking Transition Probabilities — summarise_smoking_transitions
code: summarise_smoking_transitions(config, pops)

title: Summarise and Plot Smoking Transition Probabilities — summarise_smoking_transitions
text: config Named list. Must contain: country, path (root dir), first_year, last_year. pops Data.table. Population counts (Age/Sex/Year/IMD) weighting.

what: Statistically model trends in smoking status — trend_fit
title: Statistically model trends in smoking status — trend_fit
text: Fits multinomial logistic regression "response surface" estimate Current/Former/Never status. model includes high-order polynomials Age Year, interactions Sex IMD.

title: Statistically model trends in smoking status — trend_fit
code: trend_fit(   data,   max_iterations = 1000,   age_var = "age",   year_var = "year",   sex_var = "sex",   smoker_state_var = "smk.state",   imd_var = "imd_quintile",   weight_var = "wt_int" )

title: Statistically model trends in smoking status — trend_fit
text: data Data table survey data. max_iterations Integer. age_var, year_var, sex_var, smoker_state_var, imd_var, weight_var Column names.

what: Write Transition Probability Estimates to Excel — write_excel_report
title: Write Transition Probability Estimates to Excel — write_excel_report
text: Generates multi-sheet Excel workbook professional cover sheet including detailed methodological metadata reproducibility.

title: Write Transition Probability Estimates to Excel — write_excel_report
code: write_excel_report(   config,   init_res,   quit_res,   relapse_res,   net_init_dt = NULL,   quit_no_init = NULL )

title: Write Transition Probability Estimates to Excel — write_excel_report
text: config Configuration list containing metadata model parameters. init_res Initiation results list/dataframe. quit_res Quitting results list/dataframe. relapse_res Relapse results list/dataframe. net_init_dt Optional net initiation table (can NULL). quit_no_init Optional quitting without initiation table (can NULL).
